pullRequest.body:
Given a family of `R`-modules `N` indexed by `ι ⊕ ι'`, we obtain a linear equivalence `tmulEquivDep : (⨂[R] i₁, N (.inl i₁)) ⊗[R] (⨂[R] i₂, N (.inr i₂)) ≃ₗ[R] ⨂[R] i, N i`, which generalizes `tmulEquiv` (which is the case all `N i` are the same module).

---

This will be used in #18527.

<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

### PR summary [e04b7cbd51](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/18534/commits/e04b7cbd51b2251fa47f9d7113d0d40bcbe22c2d)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ currySumEquiv_apply`
`+ currySumEquiv_symm_apply`
`+ domCoprodDep`
`+ domCoprodDep'`
`+ rec_update₁`
`+ rec_update₂`
`+ tmulEquivDep`
`+ tmulEquivDep_apply`
`+ tmulEquivDep_symm_apply`
`+ update_inl_comp_inl_apply`
`+ update_inr_comp_inr_apply`
`- coe_currySumEquiv`
`- coe_currySumEquiv_symm`
`- currySum_apply`
`- uncurrySum_aux_apply`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>Decrease in tech debt: (relative, absolute) = (2.00, 0.00)</summary>

|Current number|Change|Type|
|-:|:-:|:-|
|5094|-2|porting notes|
|1558|-2|erw|

Current commit [e04b7cbd51](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/commit/e04b7cbd51b2251fa47f9d7113d0d40bcbe22c2d)
Reference commit [672417d098](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/commit/672417d0985f271204484fc9d2078d797bffbf64)

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>
!bench
Isn't this `Sum.rec`?
Thanks! I am fixing this.

```suggestion
      update (fun j ↦ f (.inl j)) i x j :=
  congr_fun (update_comp_eq_of_injective' f Sum.inl_injective i x) j
```

I don't think that `deprecated alias` is appropriate here, since this completely changes the type of these declarations (there is a missing `.symm`!)

My preference would be to keep these as the simp-normal spellings, just as `curry` and `uncurry` are simp-normal while `Equiv.curry` is a bundling for convenience when needed.

Thanks for pointing this out. I have now used a deprecated `def` instead.

I see little reasons to use `currySum/uncurrySum` (+ `left_inv/right_inv` lemmas) instead of a single definition `currySumEquiv` (which shall be very rarely used anyway).

One argument for keeping these would be consistency with `ContinuousMultilinearMap.currySum` etc. Maybe @sgouezel and @urkud have opinions on whether the not-fully-bundled versions are worth keeping around.

Another argument for using `currySum` and `uncurrySum` as the simp-normal forms is that as terms they are significantly lightly-weight, as there is no `DFunLike.coe` term that appears with a huge set of module typeclass arguments.
The not fully bundled versions are much lighter to use in practice, so we tend to use these most of the time, and only switch to the bundled version when its properties are important.
If `(un)currySum` are to be the simp NF, in principle, we should also add lemmas expressing these plain maps are linear, etc, all of which is taken care of using a `LinearEquiv`.
The only reasonable compromise I may consider would be to define the basic `currySum/uncurrySum` as abbreviations referring to `currySumEquiv`.

Can we at split this PR into:

* Add the new dependent version of `currySum`/`uncurrySum`
* Refactor the simp-normal form (for both `MultilinearMap` and `ContinuousMultilinearMap`)

I'd prefer not to have to do the former and the latter at the same time, and the status quo is to use `currySum` and `uncurrySum` as simp-normal.

I do not see the point of splitting this PR into two.

What I am saying is that currently, we do not have basic API lemmas like `currySum_add`, `currySum_smul`, etc, not even `currySum_uncurrySum`, which we should have if the API is meant to involve the basic definitions `(un)currySum`. If everything is defined in terms of `currySumEquiv`, then we have all of these through the `LinearEquiv` API. If some people are not happy using `currySumEquiv`, they may use basic `currySum` and `uncurrySum` if these are defined as abbreviations as I am suggesting above.

I agree those lemmas are missing; my preference would be to add at least the `add` and `smul` versions (which we already prove manually anyway, so this is just a job of extracting the proofs to lemmas), and let people rewrite by `currySumEquiv_apply` if they need access to the full API. I think this is fairly consistent with how things are handled across mathlib, even if it may not be the perfect choice.
My preference is not to duplicate the generic `map_add` and `map_smul`.

I have played a lot with bundled and unbundled versions of currying maps for continuous multilinear maps, when defining higher derivatives and proving their properties (see for instance the definition https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/7b8edbb98887af54a4cb8e8f76fa279960233c22/Mathlib/Analysis/Calculus/ContDiff/FTaylorSeries.lean#L344 and basically all the corresponding file). And if I remember correctly there were sometimes weird elaboration issues when using the bundled versions, and things were slower because the types are complicated (you need to understand the algebraic / topological properties of continuous linear maps into continuous mutlilinear maps and friends whenever you write down the equiv, and this is putting typeclass inference to its knees). This is why I used the unbundled version whenever possible, and only switched to the bundled version if it was necessary -- the presence of `set_option maxSynthPendingDepth 2` in this file is an indication of what goes wrong sometimes. So, I really don't think it's a wise move to go with the bundled version as the standard one.
Do the existing non-dependent callers break if you use the old name?
Yes, it breaks, as Lean cannot guess that it has to be applied to a constant family of types.

```suggestion
@[deprecated "Use currySumEquiv.symm instead" (since := "2024-11-01")]
```
This should be a `def` too, since you've changed its type from `LinearMap` to `LinearEquiv` here.
Ah yes. I have fixed this.

```suggestion
    (MultilinearMap R (fun (i : ι') ↦ N (.inr i)) M₂) → MultilinearMap R N M₂ :=
```
was I believe the previous type of this definition

pullRequest.title: feat(LinearAlgebra/PiTensorProduct): dependent version of tmulEquiv
